awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Environmental Stochasticity for the Spatial Dynamics of Savanna-Forest Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Changing temperature and rainfall patterns globally will have  major effects on vegetation patterns, in some cases shifting the nature of ecosystems dramatically with consequences for wildlife, and for the services that natural systems provide to humans.  These “critical transitions”  are possible outcomes of environmental shifts in a wide variety of systems, including the savanna and forest transitions that this project will address, in which changes in frequency of fires can be especially important in changing the nature of these key ecosystem types. Building on previous work by the project leaders, this research will develop and apply state-of-the-art mathematical models, in concert with empirical studies, to predict how changing environmental conditions will mediate shifts in the savanna-forest boundary.  This project will also enhance education and training at multiple levels, including the training of a postdoctoral fellow; development of graduate and undergraduate research projects; and data visualization through collaboration with artist and educator Neil Goldberg.

The potential for multiple stable states, respectively forest and savanna, in vegetation systems has been previously demonstrated, combining empirical work with dynamical systems models.  The introduction of spatial effects leads to systems of partial-differential or partial differential-integral equations, including stochastic influences, which of course are more complicated to analyze, but are crucial for predicting the shifts of boundaries.  This project will develop and apply new methodologies drawn from non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, and will generate novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, developing new approaches to these stochastic systems, and applying a  novel landscape-flux approach. A key element will involve the training of a truly interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellow to be fluent both in the mathematical dimensions of the project and the ecological data analysis.

This award is funded jointly by the MPS Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) through the Mathematical Biology Program and BIO/DEB through the Cluster of Population and Community Ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Previous work by us and others has established that savanna and forest represent alternative stable states, and that spatial structure in initial conditions as a result of past climate determines their distributions. In the face of climate change, boundaries will shift, and we develop methodologies to predict how changes in temperature and precipitation mediate shifts in the savanna-forest boundary. Nonequilibrium statistical mechanical models can provide quantification of global dynamics and thermodynamics. This work also  generates novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, the connection with stochastic differential equation systems, and the novel landscape-flux approach for discovering the underlying mechanisms sustaining ecosystems.

 

 For the savanna-forest ecosystem, we solve the dynamics numerically with two alternative methods: solving the corresponding partical diffferential equation and the corresponding stochastic equations.Under the zero-fluctuation or deterministic limit, we further show, following the landscape-flux theory that the driving force can be decomposed into the sum of an intrinsic potential and an intrinsic flux velocity.  We derive these potentials and fluxes for the savanna-forest ecosystem.  This allows us to quantify the global stability of equilibria in deterministic system. We quantify the intrinsic potential and show it is a Lyapunov function monotonically decreasing along the deterministic trajectory. Numerically quantifying the potential landscape and the flux velocity allow us to characterize the global dynamics of the non-equilibrium system.  We use this to study the multiple state-transition mechanisms. We developed a stochastic path integral method for quantifying the dominant paths switching from one stable state such as Grass to another such as Tree. This can help us to find out how the process actually occurs. The derivation of the dominant paths can be used to directly determine the rate of the switching transition under the fluctuations through the potential barrier along that path. This allows us to find out how fast the process proceeds which gives another stability measure under the fluctuations.Furthemore, we design the dynamical measure in terms of the average flux and the thermodynamic measure in terms of the entropy production for early warning signals of stabilities and bifuracations/phase transitions of states in savanna-forest ecosystems.

 

Complex systems can be multistable and exhibit transitions between alternative locally stable states. We employ the landscape-flux theory from nonequilibrium statistical mechanics as a general framework to quantify the global stability of ecological systems. The average flux as the nonequilibrium driving force, the entropy production as the thermodynamic driving force, and time irreversibility of the cross-correlation functions can serve as warning signals for critical transitions between alternative stable states much earlier than other conventional predictors. We utilize a classical shallow lake model and savana-forest model as an examples for our early warning prediction based on the landscape-flux approach. The method we propose is general and can be readily applied to assess the resilience of many other complex ecological systems.

 

This work provides new early warning signals for predicting critical transitions in ecological systems. The concept and method developed here for early warning signals of critical transitions can be applied to other disciplines such as climate change,  earth science, financial markets etc. This project helps to train the post doctoral researcher and graduate students on using methods for predicting critical transitions in different systems and associated applications in different fields for academic and industrial career developments. This study provides a new method on critical transition predictions which is beneficial for the educations in not only ecology but also for other disiplines. The study should have significant influences on the policy making and strategy design based on the the early warning signals for preventions of bifurcations and catastrophy.
